problem:
\begin{problem*}{}{}
  Let $f\colon [0,1] \to \RR$ be a bounded
  function satisfying
  \[
    f(2x)=3f(x)\quad \forall \, x\in [0,{1}/{2}]
  .\]
  Prove that $\lim_{x \to 0^+} f(x)=0$.
\end{problem*}
solution:
\begin{soln}
  Note that $f(2x)=3f(x)$ for all
  $x\in \left[0,\frac{1}{2}\right]$
  which implies $f(x)=3f\left(\frac{x}{2}\right)$ for all
  $x\in [0,1]$. Similarly,
  \[
    f(x)=3f\left(\frac{x}{2}\right)=3^2f\left(\frac{x}{2^2}\right)
    =\cdots
    =3^{n}f\left(\frac{x}{2^{n}}\right)
    \quad \forall\,x \in [0,1]
  \]
  which implies $f(x)=\frac{f(2^nx)}{3^n}$ for all
  $x\in \left[0,\frac{1}{2^{n}}\right]$ and any $n\in \NN$.
  
  Also, plugging $x=0$ implies $f(x)=0$. Since $f$ is
  bounded, there exists $B>0$ such that $|f(x)|<B$ 
  for all $x\in [0,1]$.

  Fix $\eps>0$ arbitrarily. We pick
  $\delta=\frac{1}{2^N}$ where
  $N=\floor{\log_{3}\left(\frac{B}{\eps}\right)}+1$.
  Then for all $x\in (0,\delta)$ we have
  \[
    |f(x)| = \left|\frac{f(2^{N}x)}{3^{N}}\right|
    \le \frac{B}{3^N}< \eps
  \]
  which implies $\lim_{x \to 0^+} f(x)=0=f(0)$, as desired.
\end{soln}
